forecast.review: The other two forecasters provided a crucial piece of evidence that I had missed: Luis Arr치ez had a batting average over .400 into June of 2023. My initial analysis was anchored on Chipper Jones in 2008 being the last player to accomplish this, which made the event seem significantly rarer than it is. The Arr치ez example is much more recent and therefore more relevant, as it occurred in the current MLB environment with high-velocity pitchers and advanced defensive positioning. Their reasoning is highly convincing because this recent precedent directly demonstrates the feat's plausibility, shifting the base rate from something that happens once every 15-20 years to something that can and has happened in the very recent past. Both forecasters correctly balanced the rarity of the event with this powerful recent example.
forecast.rationale: My initial forecast of 15% was based on incomplete information. I believed the last time a player had a .400 average on June 1st was in 2008. The other forecasters correctly pointed out that Luis Arr치ez achieved this as recently as 2023. This is a game-changing piece of information. It provides a 'proof of concept' that a player can reach this milestone in the modern baseball era, even with the challenges of specialized, high-velocity pitching. This recent precedent is much more telling than an example from over a decade ago. It suggests that my base rate assessment was too low. While the event remains statistically unlikely due to the powerful force of regression to the mean, the fact that it has happened twice in the last 15-16 seasons (Jones in '08, Arr치ez in '23) warrants a higher probability. I am therefore updating my forecast upwards significantly, aligning with the other analysts whose assessments were based on more complete and relevant evidence.
